8 killed
640{{cite web|publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] |date=30 August 2009 |accessdate=30 August 2009 |url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/090830/world/myanmar_china_unrest_ethnic_media |title=Myanmar says 34 killed as border fighting ends |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090923044138/http://ca.news.yahoo.com/s/afp/090830/world/myanmar_china_unrest_ethnic_media |archivedate=23 September 2009 }} weapons seized | casualties2 = ''According to junta government'':
26 killed
47 wounded | casualties3 = 1 Chinese civilian killed
30,000 [[refugee|displaced]] }} {{Campaignbox Myanmar conflict}} [[File:Kokang.svg|140px|right|thumb|Location of the Kokang region (green) within Shan State (yellow).]] The '''Kokang incident''' was a violent conflict or series of [[skirmish]]es that broke out in August 2009 in [[Kokang]] in [[Myanmar]]'s northern [[Shan State]].{{cite web | url=http://www.bangkokpost.com/news/asia/152806/more-fighting-feared-as-thousands-flee-burma | title=More fighting feared as thousands flee Burma | publisher=[[Bangkok Post]] | author=[[Agence France-Presse]] | date=27 August 2009 | accessdate=28 August 2009}} Several clashes between the Burmese [[military junta]] forces (including the [[Myanmar Armed Forces]], also known as [[Tatmadaw]], and the [[Myanmar Police Force]]) and ethnic minorities took place. As a result of the conflict, the [[MNDAA]] lost control of the area and as many as 30,000 [[refugee]]s fled to [[Yunnan]] province in neighbouring [[People's Republic of China|China]].[http://edition.cnn.com/2015/02/12/asia/myanmar-violence/ 47 Myanmar soldiers reported dead in clashes with Kokang rebels] ==Events== ===Background=== Before the events, the military government had a [[cease-fire]] with most of the region's ethnic groups since 1989. Since 2008, however, the military junta has proposed that the ethnic armies (so-called "cease-fire groups"{{cite web | last=Kate | first=Daniel Ten | date=28 August 2009 | accessdate=30 August 2009 | title=Myanmar Takes Rebel-Held Town Near China Oil Projects | url=http://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=20601091&sid=anSfhGW8jick | publisher=[[Bloomberg L.P.]]}}) be assimilated into the Tatmadaw and converted into "border guards"; most of the ethnic armies have opposed this. Some political analysts claim{{Who|date=January 2012}} that the junta's motivation for this proposal is to "disarm" and "neutralize"{{cite web | last=Petty | first=Martin | work=[[Reuters]] | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009 | title=Q+A: Will fighting in northern Myanmar escalate? |url=http://www.reuters.com/article/newsMaps/idUSTRE57S0T020090829}} the cease-fire groups before the [[Burmese general election, 2010|Burmese general election]] scheduled to take place sometime in 2010. The Kokang Special region is a self-administrating area{{cite web | url=http://ngdsb.hinews.cn/html/2009-08/29/content_154639.htm | script-title=zh:果敢乱局当前 传“果敢王”已逃离 | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009|language=zh}} in northern Shan State; it has been ruled by chairman [[Pheung Kya-shin]] (Peng Jiasheng, 彭家声) since its establishment in 1989,{{cite web|title=Kokang capital falls: "Not shoot first" policy under fire |url=http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2695:kokang-capital-falls-not-shoot-first-policy-under-fire&catid=86:war&Itemid=284 |work=[[Shan Herald]] |date=26 August 2009 |accessdate=29 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902153753/http://www.shanland.org:80/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2695:kokang-capital-falls-not-shoot-first-policy-under-fire&catid=86:war&Itemid=284 |archivedate=2 September 2009 |df=dmy }} and is populated mostly by [[Kokang people]] (果敢), the name for [[Han Chinese]] living in Myanmar. Since its inception, Kokang has been implicated in the [[illegal drug trade]] and [[Drug trafficking|trafficking]] as well as [[gambling]] and prostitution.{{cite web | publisher=[[Associated Press]] | last=Bodeen | first=Christopher | url=http://www.canadaeast.com/news/article/774873 | title=Fighting in Myanmar sending refugees to China, underscoring Beijing's border woes | date=28 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009}} Kokang has its own army, the [[Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army]] (MNDAA), not to be confused with the [[National Democratic Alliance Army]] (or Mongla Group). The MNDAA reportedly has about 1,000 to 1,500 soldiers. Recently there has been an inter-faction split within the army, with Pheung being opposed by deputy chairman Bai Suoqian—while Pheung has opposed efforts to integrate the Kokang army with the Tatmadaw, Bai has supported it and gained the junta's backing. According to the newspaper ''[[Shan Herald]]'', several factions of the Kokang army have become loyal to the junta, and three high-ranking army officials informed the junta government that Pheung was secretly producing illicit weapons and drugs. ===Drug raid and standoff=== Tensions came to a head on 8 August when the junta military, acting on a tip-off from China,{{cite web | work=[[The Myanmar Times]] | url=http://www.mmtimes.com/no488/n003.htm |title=Tip from China sparked Kokang arms factory raid, says gov’t |date=14 September 2009 | author=Myint, Zaw |accessdate=17 September 2009}} moved into the region for a raid on a gun factory suspected of being a drug front{{cite web|work=[[The Irrawaddy]] |title=Kokang Thwart Burma Army Drug Raid |url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/highlight.php?art_id=16525 |date=10 August 2009 |accessdate=28 August 2009 |author=Lawi Weng |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903011415/http://www.irrawaddy.org:80/highlight.php?art_id=16525 |archivedate=3 September 2009 |df=dmy }}{{cite web | work=[[Xinhua]] | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/28/content_11955561.htm | title=Tense situation in N. Myanmar's Shan state prevails | date=28 August 2009 | accessdate=27 August 2009}} and on Kokang leader Pheung's home.{{cite web | work=[[China Daily]] | title=Situation in Myanmar's Kokang region remains | url=http://www.chinadaily.com.cn/world/2009-08/29/content_8630621.htm | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=30 August 2009}} This confrontation, according to the newspaper ''[[Shan Herald]]'', was only a "stand-off", with no shots being fired;{{cite web | date=10 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009 | title=Junta and Kokang almost come to blows | work=[[Shan Herald]] | url=http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2673:junta-and-kokang-almost-come-to-blows&catid=86:war&Itemid=284}}{{cite web | url=http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2681:kokang-returns-to-normal&catid=86:war&Itemid=284 | title=Kokang returns to "normal" | work=[[Shan Herald]] | date=17 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009}} nevertheless, it triggered a mass exodus of locals who were worried about the possibility of violence. and a resident of the Kokang regional capital [[Laukkai]] later described the city as a "[[ghost town]]".{{cite web|url=http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2678:juntas-ploy-push-kokang-to-shoot-first&catid=86:war&Itemid=284 |title=Junta's ploy: push Kokang to shoot first |date=14 August 2009 |accessdate=29 August 2009 |work=[[Shan Herald]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090901151337/http://www.shanland.org:80/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2678:juntas-ploy-push-kokang-to-shoot-first&catid=86:war&Itemid=284 |archivedate=1 September 2009 |df=dmy }} Chinese officials had to intervene in the face-off, and by 17 August officials claimed that the situation in Kokang was "normal" again. ===Violence=== {{Location map | Myanmar | label = Laukkai | mark = Green pog.svg | lat_deg = 23 | lat_min = 35 | lon_deg = 98 | lon_min = 30 | position = right | width = 180 | float = right | caption = Location of Laukkai, regional capital of Kokang }} By 20 August, however, government troops were beginning to gather near Laukkai, and Kokang leaders reportedly urged residents to "be prepared", which prompted even more people to flee.{{cite web|title=Tension sparks people to flee into China |work=[[Shan Herald]] |date=24 August 2009 |accessdate=29 August 2009 |url=http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2692:tension-sparks-people-to-flee-into-china&catid=86:war&Itemid=284 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090902153738/http://www.shanland.org:80/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=2692:tension-sparks-people-to-flee-into-china&catid=86:war&Itemid=284 |archivedate=2 September 2009 |df=dmy }} On 24 August, junta troops captured and occupied Laukkai{{cite web | title=Myanmar military moves to crush Kokang Chinese | url=http://www.earthtimes.org/articles/show/283048,myanmar-military-moves-to-crush-kokang-chinese.html | date=27 August 2009 | accessdate=28 August 2009 | work=Earth Times}} "without firing a shot".{{cite web|url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=16662 |work=[[The Irrawaddy]] |title=Junta Renews 'Divide-and-Rule' Tactic in Shan State |author=Wai Moe |date=28 August 2009 |accessdate=29 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830013458/http://www.irrawaddy.org:80/article.php?art_id=16662 |archivedate=30 August 2009 |df=dmy }} The anti-junta ''[[Kachin News]]'' claimed that the takeover was aided by a "[[mutiny]]" staged by Kokang army leaders who had become loyal to the junta.{{cite web|url=http://www.kachinnews.com/index.php/news/1062-burmese-troops-and-kokang-soldiers-clash.html |work=Kachin News |date=30 August 2009 |accessdate=30 August 2009 |title=Burmese troops and Kokang soldiers clash |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20091020173201/http://www.kachinnews.com/index.php/news/1062-burmese-troops-and-kokang-soldiers-clash.html |archivedate=20 October 2009 }} On 27 August,{{cite web | work=[[Xinhua]] | title=Fightings (sic) keep on in Myanmar's Kokang region | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/30/content_11964522.htm | date=30 August 2009 | accessdate=30 August 2009}} the Myanmar National Democratic Alliance Army began to open fire on junta troops outside the city; according to a government statement, the Kokang army raided a [[police checkpoint]] near the border. Later [[Wa people|Wa]], [[Jingpo people|Kachin]], and as many as nine other ethnic groups joined in the fighting;{{cite web | work=[[The New York Times]] | last=Fuller | first=Thomas | date=28 August 2009 | accessdate=28 August 2009 | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/29/world/asia/29myanmar.html?ref=world | title=Refugees Flee to China as Fighting Breaks Out in Myanmar}} the [[United Wa State Army]], Myanmar's largest ethnic military force, was also involved in the fighting, as was the [[National Democratic Alliance Army]] (also known as Mong La).{{cite web | work=[[The Irrawaddy]] | date=28 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009 | title=Burmese Cease Fire Breaks Down | url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/article.php?art_id=16658 | author=Saw Yan Naing}} On 27 and 28 there were more battles in the villages of [[Yan Lon Kyaik]] and [[Chin Swe Haw]], near the Chinese border. Across the border, the Chinese army increased its numbers in attempt to maintain border stability. By late 29 August, the United States-based [[Campaign for Burma]] claimed that as many as 700 Kokang fighters, outnumbered by junta troops, had fled, surrendered to the Chinese, and given up their weapons.{{cite web | url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/sns-ap-as-china-myanmar,0,2397711.story |work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|author=Ng Han Guan| title=Ethnic rebels flee Myanmar, abandoning weapons and uniforms for safe haven in south China | accessdate=30 August 2009}}{{cite web | work=[[The Irrawaddy]] | author=Wai Moe | title=Fighting Stops as Kokang Surrender Arms to Chinese | date=30 August 2009 | accessdate=30 August 2009 | url=http://www.irrawaddy.org/highlight.php?art_id=16667}} Kokang soldiers interviewed in China after surrendering also said they had been overrun.{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2009/08/20098306161918344.html | title=Myanmar fighters cross into China | work=[[Al Jazeera News]] | date=30 August 2009 | accessdate=30 August 2009}} While the Kokang army appears to have been routed, the larger United Wa State Army was still active, and [[Al Jazeera]] reported that the government was requesting reinforcements to deal with them; the ''[[New York Times]]'', however, reported that the Wa army had withdrawn as early as 28 August.{{cite web | last=Fuller | first=Thomas | work=[[The New York Times]] | date=30 August 2009 | accessdate=30 August 2009 | title=Myanmar Forces Overwhelm Rebels | url=http://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/31/world/asia/31iht-myanmar.html?hp}} The government issued a statement on 30 August claiming that the fighting had ended, and later formed a new "Kokang Region Provisional Leading Committee" in Laukkai.{{cite web | work=[[Xinhua]] | date=1 September 2009 | accessdate=2 September 2009 | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-09/01/content_11980792.htm | title=More than 2,800 Myanmar border inhabitants return to Kokang after fightings end}} Myanmar army operation in that incident was overseen by [[Min Aung Hlaing]] and he was credited for it.{{cite web|title=Senior General Min Aung Hlaing|url=http://www.altsean.org/Research/Regime%20Watch/Executive/CIC.php|website=http://www.altsean.org/|accessdate=27 February 2015}} ==Casualties and refugees== No official casualty count was released in the first two days of fighting, although Pheung Kya-shin claimed that his forces had killed over thirty Tatmadaw troops.{{cite web | url=http://world.globaltimes.cn/asia-pacific/2009-08/462324.html | title=Over 30 gov't soldiers killed; civil war possible in Myanmar | work=[[Global Times]] | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009}} One Chinese person was killed during fighting when a bomb went over the border.{{cite web | work=[[The Times of India]] | title=Fresh violence near China-Myanmar border | url=http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2009-08-29/china/28159665_1_myanmar-military-junta-myanmar-government-myanmarese | last=Dasgupta | first=Saibal | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}[https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5gaS4NOB2jmkI6M2kJJ3-QBnOfEWQ 1 killed by bomb along China-Myanmar border: media]. AFP. 29 August 2009. On 30 August, the junta government released its first figures, claiming that the fighting had killed twenty-six junta troops (fifteen police, eleven soldiers) and wounded forty-seven (thirteen police, thirty-four soldiers), and that eight rebel bodies had been found so far; the figures have not been independently confirmed, however. From 8 to 12 August, as many as 10,000 residents fled to [[Yunnan]] province in neighbouring China, becoming [[refugee]]s.{{cite web | work=[[BBC News]] | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8223430.stm | title='Thousands Flee Burma Violence' | date=26 August 2009 | accessdate=28 August 2009}} The total number of refugees fleeing in the entire month may be as high as 30,000, according to the [[United Nations]] High Commissioner for Refugees and later the [[Yunnan]] provincial government.Tran, Tini (29 August 2009). [https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5h3erz_xCOMgFXnPSD0FMVpWMWikgD9ACKP6G4 New Myanmar clashes leave 1 dead, dozens injured]. [[Associated Press]]. Yunnan's police chief later reported that the number of refugees in Yunnan reached 37,000, including Burmese refugees as well as Kokang.{{cite web | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-08/31/content_11968443.htm | work=[[Xinhua]] | date=30 August 2009 | accessdate=31 August 2009 | title=Myanmar border inhabitants begin to return from China as situation calms }}{{cite web | work=[[Reuters]] | date=31 August 2009 | accessdate=31 August 2009 | title=Myanmar refugees weigh risks of returning from China | last=Buckley | first=Chris | url=http://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE57S0IR20090831}} Yunnan government officials stated they have established seven locations (particularly near the city of [[Nansan]], where most of the refugees arrived) to house and treat the refugees; some locals, however, claimed that not all the refugees were being housed, or were being housed in unfinished buildings and tents. According to one refugee, about 13,000 of the refugees were housed in the tents, and 10,000–20,000 more stayed with friends or family in the area.{{cite web | url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/asia-pacific/2009/08/200983173936250395.html | title=Myanmar refugees wary of return | work=[[Al Jazeera]] | date=31 August 2009 | accessdate=31 August 2009}} By 31 August, some refugees (as many as 4,000, according to local officials,{{cite web | publisher=[[Associated Press]] | url=http://www.miamiherald.com/news/world/AP/story/1210766.html | author=Ng Han Guan | date=31 August 2009 | accessdate=31 August 2009 | title=Myanmar refugees begin to return home from China}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}} or 2,800 according to the junta government) had started returning to Kokang;{{cite web | url=http://www.voanews.com/english/2009-08-31-voa19.cfm | work=[[Voice of America News]] | date=31 August 2009 | accessdate=31 August 2009 | last=Shearf | first=Daniel | title=Burma Refugees in China Head Home as Fighting Dies Down}} by mid-September, Chinese officials said over 9,000 refugeees had returned{{cite journal | title=Emerging Fault Lines in Sino-Burmese Relations: The Kokang Incident | url=http://www.jamestown.org/single/?no_cache=1&tx_ttnews[tt_news]=35468&tx_ttnews[backPid]=7&cHash=3cc6a7017c | journal=China Brief | volume=19 | issue=8 | last=Storey | first=Ian | date=10 September 2009 | accessdate=11 September 2009}} and Myanmar officials said over 13,000;{{cite web | title=Myanmar says market trading in Kokang capital returns to normal | work=[[Xinhua]] | date=7 September 2009 | accessdate=11 September 2009 | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-09/07/content_12009467.htm}} many refugees, however, were still afraid to go back. Pheung was also rumoured to have fled Kokang,{{cite web | url=http://ngdsb.hinews.cn/html/2009-08/29/content_154639.htm | script-title=zh:果敢乱局当前 传“果敢王”已逃离 | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009 | quote=传言果敢特区领导人彭家声已经逃离。
''English'': "It is rumored that the leader of the Kokang Special Region, Peng Jiasheng, has also fled."|language=zh}} and is currently in China,{{cite web | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | title=Myanmar troops attack minority militia in the north | url=http://www.latimes.com/news/nationworld/world/la-fg-myanmar-fighting30-2009aug30,0,4841699.story | last=Magnier | first=Mark | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009}} although his precise location has not been revealed. Before the Kokang forces surrendered, he claimed that he was still controlling them from abroad. ==Reaction== Although China has in the past supported the military junta, during the conflict, it had instead warned Myanmar to end the situation, saying they should "properly handle domestic problems and maintain stability in the China-Myanmar border region"{{cite web | last=Johnson | first=Tim | date=29 August 2009 | accessdate=29 August 2009 | url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/08/28/AR2009082803764.html | title=China Urges Burma to Bridle Ethnic Militia Uprising at Border | work=[[The Washington Post]]}} and urging Burma to protect "Chinese citizens in Myanmar". Chinese officials were said to be "furious" and "{{sic|extermely}} upset" over not being forewarned about the offensive on the border. Chinese and other analysts expressed concern that this conflict could lead to a [[civil war]] in Burma. The Burmese Foreign Ministry later apologised to China about the incident, but also ran a story on the [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]] in the government newspaper the ''[[The Myanmar Times|Myanmar Times]]'', the first mention of him in the [[State media|state controlled]] [[Media of Burma|Burmese media]] for 20 years.Jagan, Larry (1 September 2009). [http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Southeast_Asia/KI01Ae04.html Border war rattles China-Myanmar ties]. ''[[Asia Times Online]]''. The [[United Nations]] has also expressed concern about reports of fighting and thousands of refugees fleeing across the border.Islam, Siddique (29 August 2009). [http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016243547?U.N.%20Voices%20Concern%20As%20Fresh%20Fighting%20Breaks%20Out%20In%20Northeastern%20Burma U.N. Voices Concern As Fresh Fighting Breaks Out In Northeastern Burma] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090903032012/http://www.allheadlinenews.com/articles/7016243547?U.N.%20Voices%20Concern%20As%20Fresh%20Fighting%20Breaks%20Out%20In%20Northeastern%20Burma |date=3 September 2009 }}. AHN. The [[United States]] government also voiced its concern, and called on the junta to end its military campaign against the cease-fire groups.{{cite web | work=[[Xinhua]] | date=31 August 2009 | accessdate=31 August 2009 | url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-09/01/content_11974326.htm | title=U.S. urges end to violence in Myanmar}} ==Aftermath== After the fighting ended, the new Kokang leader claimed that the Kokang people would participate in the 2010 general elections; other cease-fire groups such as the Wa and Kachin still maintain that they will not participate.{{cite news | title=Myanmar says Chinese tip-off led to border clash | publisher=[[The Associated Press]] | date=10 September 2009 | accessdate=11 September 2009 | url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5i2nUHOdn-KZ9M9fpx0qKHABSXhQgD9AK72Q02}} [[Bai Xuoqian]], vice-president under Peng Jiasheng, become new head of KoKang with the support of ruling junta in 2009. The portion of the MNDAA loyal to him became Border Guard Force #1006. He is also head of Kokang Self Administered Zone and a member of Myanmar parliament in 2011.{{cite web|url=http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option%3Dcom_content%26view%3Darticle%26id%3D4452%3Akokang-wants-to-join-ceasefire-talks%26catid%3D85%3Apolitics%26Itemid%3D266 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-05-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140913081914/http://www.shanland.org/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=4452:kokang-wants-to-join-ceasefire-talks&catid=85:politics&Itemid=266 |archivedate=13 September 2014 |df=dmy }} The area was peaceful till new clashes between Peng Jiasheng's troops and Myanmar troops erupted in February 2015.{{cite web|last1=Khin Maung Win|agency=[[Associated Press]]|title=Myanmar says Kokang rebels on the run despite allies' help|url=http://www.stripes.com/news/pacific/myanmar-says-kokang-rebels-on-the-run-despite-allies-help-1.331007|publisher=[[Stars and Stripes (newspaper)|Stars and Stripes]]|accessdate=24 February 2015}} Major General Huang Xing, the former head of the research guidance department at the [[Chinese Academy of Military Science]], was ousted in 2015 because of his relationship with MNDAA during this incident.{{cite web|last1=Minnie Chan|title=Senior Chinese military strategist ‘leaked state secrets, helped rebels in Myanmar’|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/article/1730837/pla-military-strategist-leaked-state-secrets-helped-myanmar-rebels|work=[[South China Morning Post]]|accessdate=8 March 2015}} ==See also==
